comment_text.mn119:1.1: This discourse features the same meditation practices found under the “observation of the body” in the Satipaṭṭhānasutta (MN 10).
comment_text.mn119:4.7: For “memories and thoughts tied to lay life” (gehasitā sarasaṅkappā) see MN 125:23.5 and SN 54.8:5.2. | Sarasaṅkappā may be translated in two ways. Bodhi reads it as a dvanda compound (“memories and thoughts”), which takes sara as “memory” (Sanskrit smara or smṛti). The commentary, followed by Ānandajoti, explains it as dhāvanasaṅkappā (“rushing thoughts”), which assumes the sense “flow” (Sanskrit saras). Support for the dvanda interpretation comes from Sanskrit texts, where we frequently find smṛtisaṁkalpa as either two words (eg. Aitareya Upaniṣad 3.2) or a compound (Nyāyasūtra 4.2.34).
comment_text.mn119:4.8: Each practice leads directly to immersion, reminding us that mindfulness meditation is “the basis of immersion” (samādhinimitta, MN 44:12.3).
comment_text.mn119:6.1: Obviously this passage is not suggesting that one enters deep meditation while going to the toilet. As per the Gradual Training, such practices form a foundation that prepares the mind for meditation.
comment_text.mn119:7.7: Such meditations, as also the contemplation on death that follow, lead to immersion by ridding the mind of desire. While the subject of meditation is perceived as unpleasant, when the mind is free of desire it gives rise to a pleasure imbued with lightness and freedom, and it is that pleasure that leads to immersion.
comment_text.mn119:18.1: In the Satipaṭṭhānasutta, the practice of absorption is implicit in the contemplation of feelings (as spiritual pleasure), mind (as immersed mind, etc.), and principles (as the awakening factor of immersion), while the four absorptions are mentioned explicitly in the expanded version (DN 22:21.32). Here they take an even more central role.
comment_text.mn119:18.2: As a meditator proceeds, their subjective experience of the “body” evolves from tactile sense impressions (phoṭṭhabba), to the interior mental experience of bliss and light (manomayakāya), to the direct personal realization of highest truth (MN 70:23.2: kāyena ceva paramasaccaṁ sacchikaroti).
comment_text.mn119:18.3: The kneading is the “placing the mind and keeping it connected”, the water is bliss, while the lack of leaking speaks to the contained interiority of the experience.
comment_text.mn119:19.3: The simile emphasizes the water as bliss, while the lack of inflow expresses containment and unification. The water welling up is the rapture, which is the uplifting emotional response to the experience of bliss. These similes are also at DN 2:78.1, DN 10:2.16.1, MN 39.16, MN 77:26.3, and AN 5.28:3.4.
comment_text.mn119:20.3: The meditator is utterly immersed in stillness and bliss.
comment_text.mn119:21.3: The white cloth is the purity and brightness of equanimity. The commentary explains this as a person who has just got out of a bath and sits perfectly dry and content.
comment_text.mn119:22.1: By this, the Buddha is asserting that mindfulness of the body is not just the first of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, but encompasses all of them. The body is the arena within which feelings, mind, and principles become apparent. (Also at AN 1.575.) | The things that “play a part in realization” are enumerated as two at AN 2.31: serenity and discernment. Another group of six at SN 55.3:4.1 and AN 6.35 focus on the discernment side (observing impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, fading away, and cessation).
comment_text.mn119:22.2: A simile of the rivers becoming united in the ocean is also found at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.11, Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad 3.2.8, and Praśna Upaniṣad 6.5.
comment_text.mn119:26.2: Compare the simile at Chāndogya Upaniṣad 1.2.7 and Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.3.7, where the titans (or forces of evil) meet their end in the breath, just like a clod of earth thrown against solid rock.
comment_text.mn119:28.1: These similes recall the absorption similes above.
comment_text.mn119:29.5: The phrase sati sati āyatane is tricky. Syntactically, it is a locative absolute construction, which Bodhi treats as conditional: “there being a suitable basis”. However this does not readily account for the repeated sati, which he takes as the locative present participle from the verb atthi (“being”). Ānandajoti, by contrast, takes the first sati as “being” and the second as “mindfulness”, and treats the absolute construction as temporal: “while there is a basis for mindfulness”. Further, both accept the commentary’s gloss of āyatana as kāraṇa (“reason, basis”), although this sense of āyatana is rare in the suttas (but see SN 12.25:14.3 = AN 4.171:5.3). These readings of the absolute construction give it a limiting sense; the benefits apply only insofar as there is a “suitable basis” or a “basis for mindfulness”. But the expression is used by the Buddha of himself (AN 5.68:1.9), so it seems odd that it would be limiting. Indeed, the tenor of the whole sentence is not limiting but expansive, as emphasized by the repeated reduplications: yassa yassa … tatra tatreva … sati sati, which have a distributive sense. I therefore take sati as “being” in both cases; the reduplication of sati as aligned with the preceding pronouns, emphasizing universality; the locative absolute as causal; and āyatana in its normal sense of “scope, range”.

root_text.mn119:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn119:2.1: Atha kho sambahulānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṁ upaṭṭhānasālāyaṁ sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
root_text.mn119:2.3: Yāvañcidaṁ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā vuttā mahānisaṁsā”ti.
root_text.mn119:2.4: Ayañca hidaṁ tesaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ antarākathā vippakatā hoti, atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena upaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
root_text.mn119:2.6: “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
root_text.mn119:2.7: “Idha, bhante, amhākaṁ pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṁ upaṭṭhānasālāyaṁ sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
root_text.mn119:2.9: Yāvañcidaṁ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā vuttā mahānisaṁsā’ti.
root_text.mn119:2.10: Ayaṁ kho no, bhante, antarākathā vippakatā, atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.
root_text.mn119:3.1: “Kathaṁ bhāvitā ca, bhikkhave, kāyagatāsati kathaṁ bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṁsā?
root_text.mn119:4.1: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
root_text.mn119:4.3: dīghaṁ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṁ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, dīghaṁ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti;
root_text.mn119:4.4: rassaṁ vā assasanto ‘rassaṁ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṁ vā passasanto ‘rassaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti;
root_text.mn119:4.6: ‘passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
root_text.mn119:4.7: Tassa evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
root_text.mn119:4.8: Tesaṁ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṁ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
root_text.mn119:5.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gacchanto vā ‘gacchāmī’ti pajānāti, ṭhito vā ‘ṭhitomhī’ti pajānāti, nisinno vā ‘nisinnomhī’ti pajānāti, sayāno vā ‘sayānomhī’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn119:5.2: Yathā yathā vā panassa kāyo paṇihito hoti tathā tathā naṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn119:5.3: Tassa evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
root_text.mn119:5.4: Tesaṁ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṁ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
root_text.mn119:6.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
root_text.mn119:6.2: Tassa evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
root_text.mn119:6.3: Tesaṁ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṁ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
root_text.mn119:7.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ uddhaṁ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṁ pūraṁ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati:
root_text.mn119:7.2: ‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco maṁsaṁ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṁ vakkaṁ hadayaṁ yakanaṁ kilomakaṁ pihakaṁ papphāsaṁ antaṁ antaguṇaṁ udariyaṁ karīsaṁ pittaṁ semhaṁ pubbo lohitaṁ sedo medo assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttan’ti.
root_text.mn119:7.3: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ubhatomukhā putoḷi pūrā nānāvihitassa dhaññassa, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn119:7.4: sālīnaṁ vīhīnaṁ muggānaṁ māsānaṁ tilānaṁ taṇḍulānaṁ,
root_text.mn119:7.6: ‘ime sālī ime vīhī ime muggā ime māsā ime tilā ime taṇḍulā’ti;
root_text.mn119:7.7: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ uddhaṁ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṁ pūraṁ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati:
root_text.mn119:7.8: ‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco maṁsaṁ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṁ vakkaṁ hadayaṁ yakanaṁ kilomakaṁ pihakaṁ papphāsaṁ antaṁ antaguṇaṁ udariyaṁ karīsaṁ pittaṁ semhaṁ pubbo lohitaṁ sedo medo assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttan’ti.
root_text.mn119:7.9: Tassa evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
root_text.mn119:7.10: Tesaṁ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṁ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
root_text.mn119:8.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ yathāṭhitaṁ yathāpaṇihitaṁ dhātuso paccavekkhati:
root_text.mn119:8.2: ‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
root_text.mn119:8.3: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā gāviṁ vadhitvā catumahāpathe bilaso vibhajitvā nisinno assa;
root_text.mn119:8.4: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ yathāṭhitaṁ yathāpaṇihitaṁ dhātuso paccavekkhati:
root_text.mn119:8.5: ‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
root_text.mn119:8.6: Tassa evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
root_text.mn119:8.7: Tesaṁ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṁ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
root_text.mn119:9.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ ekāhamataṁ vā dvīhamataṁ vā tīhamataṁ vā uddhumātakaṁ vinīlakaṁ vipubbakajātaṁ.
root_text.mn119:9.4: Tassa evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
root_text.mn119:9.5: Tesaṁ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṁ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
root_text.mn119:10.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ kākehi vā khajjamānaṁ kulalehi vā khajjamānaṁ gijjhehi vā khajjamānaṁ kaṅkehi vā khajjamānaṁ sunakhehi vā khajjamānaṁ byagghehi vā khajjamānaṁ dīpīhi vā khajjamānaṁ siṅgālehi vā khajjamānaṁ vividhehi vā pāṇakajātehi khajjamānaṁ.
root_text.mn119:11-14.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṁ samaṁsalohitaṁ nhārusambandhaṁ …pe…
root_text.mn119:11-14.4: aṭṭhikāni apagatasambandhāni disāvidisāvikkhittāni aññena hatthaṭṭhikaṁ aññena pādaṭṭhikaṁ aññena gopphakaṭṭhikaṁ aññena jaṅghaṭṭhikaṁ aññena ūruṭṭhikaṁ aññena kaṭiṭṭhikaṁ aññena phāsukaṭṭhikaṁ aññena piṭṭhiṭṭhikaṁ aññena khandhaṭṭhikaṁ aññena gīvaṭṭhikaṁ aññena hanukaṭṭhikaṁ aññena dantaṭṭhikaṁ aññena sīsakaṭāhaṁ.
root_text.mn119:15-17.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ—
root_text.mn119:18.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn119:18.2: So imameva kāyaṁ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn119:18.3: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho nhāpako vā nhāpakantevāsī vā kaṁsathāle nhānīyacuṇṇāni ākiritvā udakena paripphosakaṁ paripphosakaṁ sanneyya, sāyaṁ nhānīyapiṇḍi snehānugatā snehaparetā santarabāhirā phuṭā snehena na ca pagghariṇī;
root_text.mn119:18.4: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati; nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn119:19.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn119:19.2: So imameva kāyaṁ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati; nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn119:19.3: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, udakarahado gambhīro ubbhidodako. Tassa nevassa puratthimāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ na pacchimāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ na uttarāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ na dakkhiṇāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ; devo ca na kālena kālaṁ sammā dhāraṁ anuppaveccheyya; atha kho tamhāva udakarahadā sītā vāridhārā ubbhijjitvā tameva udakarahadaṁ sītena vārinā abhisandeyya parisandeyya paripūreyya paripphareyya, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato udakarahadassa sītena vārinā apphuṭaṁ assa;
root_text.mn119:19.4: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn119:20.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn119:20.2: So imameva kāyaṁ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn119:20.3: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uppaliniyaṁ vā paduminiyaṁ vā puṇḍarīkiniyaṁ vā appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṁvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni antonimuggaposīni, tāni yāva caggā yāva ca mūlā sītena vārinā abhisannāni parisannāni paripūrāni paripphuṭāni, nāssa kiñci sabbāvataṁ uppalānaṁ vā padumānaṁ vā puṇḍarīkānaṁ vā sītena vārinā apphuṭaṁ assa;
root_text.mn119:20.4: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn119:21.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn119:21.2: So imameva kāyaṁ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti; nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn119:21.3: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso odātena vatthena sasīsaṁ pārupitvā nisinno assa, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa odātena vatthena apphuṭaṁ assa;
root_text.mn119:21.4: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn119:21.5: Tassa evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
root_text.mn119:21.6: Tesaṁ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṁ santiṭṭhati, sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
root_text.mn119:22.1: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, antogadhāvāssa kusalā dhammā ye keci vijjābhāgiyā.
root_text.mn119:22.2: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci mahāsamuddo cetasā phuṭo, antogadhāvāssa kunnadiyo yā kāci samuddaṅgamā;
root_text.mn119:22.3: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, antogadhāvāssa kusalā dhammā ye keci vijjābhāgiyā.
root_text.mn119:23.1: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, kāyagatāsati abhāvitā abahulīkatā, labhati tassa māro otāraṁ, labhati tassa māro ārammaṇaṁ.
root_text.mn119:23.2: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso garukaṁ silāguḷaṁ allamattikāpuñje pakkhipeyya.
root_text.mn119:23.4: api nu taṁ garukaṁ silāguḷaṁ allamattikāpuñje labhetha otāran”ti?
root_text.mn119:23.6: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati abhāvitā abahulīkatā, labhati tassa māro otāraṁ, labhati tassa māro ārammaṇaṁ.
root_text.mn119:24.5: api nu so puriso amuṁ sukkhaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ koḷāpaṁ uttarāraṇiṁ ādāya abhimanthento aggiṁ abhinibbatteyya, tejo pātukareyyā”ti?
root_text.mn119:24.7: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati abhāvitā abahulīkatā, labhati tassa māro otāraṁ, labhati tassa māro ārammaṇaṁ.
root_text.mn119:25.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, udakamaṇiko ritto tuccho ādhāre ṭhapito;
root_text.mn119:25.4: api nu so puriso labhetha udakassa nikkhepanan”ti?
root_text.mn119:25.6: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati abhāvitā abahulīkatā, labhati tassa māro otāraṁ, labhati tassa māro ārammaṇaṁ.
root_text.mn119:26.1: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, na tassa labhati māro otāraṁ, na tassa labhati māro ārammaṇaṁ.
root_text.mn119:26.2: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso lahukaṁ suttaguḷaṁ sabbasāramaye aggaḷaphalake pakkhipeyya.
root_text.mn119:26.4: api nu so puriso taṁ lahukaṁ suttaguḷaṁ sabbasāramaye aggaḷaphalake labhetha otāran”ti?
root_text.mn119:26.6: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, na tassa labhati māro otāraṁ, na tassa labhati māro ārammaṇaṁ.
root_text.mn119:27.5: api nu so puriso amuṁ allaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ sasnehaṁ uttarāraṇiṁ ādāya abhimanthento aggiṁ abhinibbatteyya, tejo pātukareyyā”ti?
root_text.mn119:27.7: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, na tassa labhati māro otāraṁ, na tassa labhati māro ārammaṇaṁ.
root_text.mn119:28.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, udakamaṇiko pūro udakassa samatittiko kākapeyyo ādhāre ṭhapito;
root_text.mn119:28.4: api nu so puriso labhetha udakassa nikkhepanan”ti?
root_text.mn119:28.6: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, na tassa labhati māro otāraṁ, na tassa labhati māro ārammaṇaṁ.
root_text.mn119:29.1: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, so yassa yassa abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittaṁ abhininnāmeti abhiññāsacchikiriyāya, tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṁ pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane.
root_text.mn119:29.2: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, udakamaṇiko pūro udakassa samatittiko kākapeyyo ādhāre ṭhapito.
root_text.mn119:29.3: Tamenaṁ balavā puriso yato yato āviñcheyya, āgaccheyya udakan”ti?
root_text.mn119:29.5: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā so, yassa yassa abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittaṁ abhininnāmeti abhiññāsacchikiriyāya, tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṁ pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane.
root_text.mn119:30.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, same bhūmibhāge caturassā pokkharaṇī assa āḷibandhā pūrā udakassa samatittikā kākapeyyā.
root_text.mn119:30.2: Tamenaṁ balavā puriso yato yato āḷiṁ muñceyya āgaccheyya udakan”ti?
root_text.mn119:30.4: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, so yassa yassa abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittaṁ abhininnāmeti abhiññāsacchikiriyāya, tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṁ pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane.
root_text.mn119:31.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, subhūmiyaṁ catumahāpathe ājaññaratho yutto assa ṭhito odhastapatodo;
root_text.mn119:31.2: tamenaṁ dakkho yoggācariyo assadammasārathi abhiruhitvā vāmena hatthena rasmiyo gahetvā dakkhiṇena hatthena patodaṁ gahetvā yenicchakaṁ yadicchakaṁ sāreyyāpi paccāsāreyyāpi;
root_text.mn119:31.3: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, so yassa yassa abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittaṁ abhininnāmeti abhiññāsacchikiriyāya, tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṁ pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane.
root_text.mn119:32.1: Kāyagatāya, bhikkhave, satiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya dasānisaṁsā pāṭikaṅkhā.
root_text.mn119:33.1: Aratiratisaho hoti, na ca taṁ arati sahati, uppannaṁ aratiṁ abhibhuyya viharati.
root_text.mn119:34.1: Bhayabheravasaho hoti, na ca taṁ bhayabheravaṁ sahati, uppannaṁ bhayabheravaṁ abhibhuyya viharati.
root_text.mn119:35.1: Khamo hoti sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya pipāsāya ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ duruttānaṁ durāgatānaṁ vacanapathānaṁ, uppannānaṁ sārīrikānaṁ vedanānaṁ dukkhānaṁ tibbānaṁ kharānaṁ kaṭukānaṁ asātānaṁ amanāpānaṁ pāṇaharānaṁ adhivāsakajātiko hoti.
root_text.mn119:36.1: Catunnaṁ jhānānaṁ ābhicetasikānaṁ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṁ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
root_text.mn119:37.1: So anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccānubhoti. Ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti, āvibhāvaṁ …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vatteti.
root_text.mn119:38.1: Dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca, ye dūre santike ca …pe….
root_text.mn119:39.1: Parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti.
root_text.mn119:40.1: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
root_text.mn119:41.1: Dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
root_text.mn119:42.1: Āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn119:43.1: Kāyagatāya, bhikkhave, satiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya ime dasānisaṁsā pāṭikaṅkhā”ti.
root_text.mn119:43.3: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn119:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn119:2.1: Then after the meal, on return from almsround, several mendicants sat together in the assembly hall and this discussion came up among them.
translation_text.mn119:2.3: how the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha has said that mindfulness of the body, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.”
translation_text.mn119:2.4: But their conversation was left unfinished. Then the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the assembly hall. He sat on the seat spread out
translation_text.mn119:2.6: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
translation_text.mn119:2.7: So the mendicants told him what they had been talking about. The Buddha said:
translation_text.mn119:3.1: “And how, mendicants, is mindfulness of the body developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?
translation_text.mn119:4.1: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.
translation_text.mn119:4.2: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.
translation_text.mn119:4.3: Breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’
translation_text.mn119:4.4: When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ Breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’
translation_text.mn119:4.5: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’
translation_text.mn119:4.6: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the physical process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the physical process.’
translation_text.mn119:4.7: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
translation_text.mn119:4.8: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
translation_text.mn119:4.9: That’s how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
translation_text.mn119:5.1: Furthermore, when a mendicant is walking they know ‘I am walking’. When standing they know ‘I am standing’. When sitting they know ‘I am sitting’. And when lying down they know ‘I am lying down’.
translation_text.mn119:5.2: Whatever posture their body is in, they know it.
translation_text.mn119:5.3: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
translation_text.mn119:5.4: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
translation_text.mn119:5.5: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
translation_text.mn119:6.1: Furthermore, a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
translation_text.mn119:6.2: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
translation_text.mn119:6.3: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
translation_text.mn119:6.4: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
translation_text.mn119:7.1: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth.
translation_text.mn119:7.2: ‘In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’
translation_text.mn119:7.3: It’s as if there were a bag with openings at both ends, filled with various kinds of grains, such as
translation_text.mn119:7.4: fine rice, wheat, mung beans, peas, sesame, and ordinary rice.
translation_text.mn119:7.5: And a person with clear eyes were to open it and examine the contents:
translation_text.mn119:7.6: ‘These grains are fine rice, these are wheat, these are mung beans, these are peas, these are sesame, and these are ordinary rice.’
translation_text.mn119:7.7: In the same way, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth. …
translation_text.mn119:7.9: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
translation_text.mn119:7.10: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
translation_text.mn119:7.11: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
translation_text.mn119:8.1: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements:
translation_text.mn119:8.2: ‘In this body there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’
translation_text.mn119:8.3: It’s as if a deft butcher or butcher’s apprentice were to kill a cow and sit down at the crossroads with the meat cut into chops.
translation_text.mn119:8.4: In the same way, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements:
translation_text.mn119:8.5: ‘In this body there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’
translation_text.mn119:8.6: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
translation_text.mn119:8.7: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
translation_text.mn119:8.8: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
translation_text.mn119:9.1: Furthermore, suppose a mendicant were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
translation_text.mn119:9.2: They’d compare it with their own body:
translation_text.mn119:9.3: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’
translation_text.mn119:9.4: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
translation_text.mn119:9.5: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
translation_text.mn119:9.6: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
translation_text.mn119:10.1: Or suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, hounds, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures.
translation_text.mn119:10.2: They’d compare it with their own body:
translation_text.mn119:10.3: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’
translation_text.mn119:10.5: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
translation_text.mn119:11-14.1: Furthermore, suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground, a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews …
translation_text.mn119:11-14.2: A skeleton without flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews …
translation_text.mn119:11-14.3: A skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews …
translation_text.mn119:11-14.4: Bones rid of sinews scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here an ankle bone, there a shin-bone, here a thigh-bone, there a hip-bone, here a rib-bone, there a back-bone, here an arm-bone, there a neck-bone, here a jaw-bone, there a tooth, here the skull. …
translation_text.mn119:15-17.2: White bones, the color of shells …
translation_text.mn119:15-17.3: Decrepit bones, heaped in a pile …
translation_text.mn119:15-17.4: Bones rotted and crumbled to powder.
translation_text.mn119:15-17.5: They’d compare it with their own body:
translation_text.mn119:15-17.6: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’
translation_text.mn119:15-17.7: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to lay life are given up.
translation_text.mn119:15-17.8: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
translation_text.mn119:15-17.9: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
translation_text.mn119:18.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn119:18.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
translation_text.mn119:18.3: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.
translation_text.mn119:18.4: In the same way, they drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
translation_text.mn119:18.5: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to lay life are given up.
translation_text.mn119:18.6: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
translation_text.mn119:18.7: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
translation_text.mn119:19.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn119:19.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
translation_text.mn119:19.3: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water. There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and the heavens would not properly bestow showers from time to time. But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake. There’s no part of the lake that’s not spread through with cool water.
translation_text.mn119:19.4: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
translation_text.mn119:19.6: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
translation_text.mn119:20.1: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption. They meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn119:20.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
translation_text.mn119:20.3: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water. There’s no part of them that’s not soaked with cool water.
translation_text.mn119:20.4: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
translation_text.mn119:20.6: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
translation_text.mn119:21.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn119:21.2: They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not filled with pure bright mind.
translation_text.mn119:21.3: It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread over with white cloth.
translation_text.mn119:21.4: In the same way, they sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not filled with pure bright mind.
translation_text.mn119:21.5: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
translation_text.mn119:21.6: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
translation_text.mn119:21.7: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
translation_text.mn119:22.1: Anyone who has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body includes all of the skillful qualities that play a part in realization.
translation_text.mn119:22.2: Anyone who brings into their mind the great ocean includes all of the streams that run down into it.
translation_text.mn119:22.3: In the same way, anyone who has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body includes all of the skillful qualities that play a part in realization.
translation_text.mn119:23.1: When a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets an opportunity.
translation_text.mn119:23.2: Suppose a person were to throw a heavy stone ball at a mound of wet clay.
translation_text.mn119:23.4: Would that heavy stone ball find an entry into that mound of wet clay?”
translation_text.mn119:23.6: “In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets an opportunity.
translation_text.mn119:24.1: Suppose there was a dried up, withered log.
translation_text.mn119:24.2: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking
translation_text.mn119:24.3: to light a fire and produce heat.
translation_text.mn119:24.5: By drilling the stick against that dried up, withered log, could they light a fire and produce heat?”
translation_text.mn119:24.7: “In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets an opportunity.
translation_text.mn119:25.1: Suppose a water jar was placed on a stand, empty and hollow.
translation_text.mn119:25.2: Then a person comes along with a load of water.
translation_text.mn119:25.4: Could that person pour water into the jar?”
translation_text.mn119:25.6: “In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets an opportunity.
translation_text.mn119:26.1: When a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get an opportunity.
translation_text.mn119:26.2: Suppose a person were to throw a light ball of string at a door-panel made entirely of hardwood.
translation_text.mn119:26.4: Would that light ball of string find an entry into that door-panel made entirely of hardwood?”
translation_text.mn119:26.6: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get an opportunity.
translation_text.mn119:27.1: Suppose there was a green, sappy log.
translation_text.mn119:27.2: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking
translation_text.mn119:27.3: to light a fire and produce heat.
translation_text.mn119:27.5: By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”
translation_text.mn119:27.7: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get an opportunity.
translation_text.mn119:28.1: Suppose a water jar was placed on a stand, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
translation_text.mn119:28.2: Then a person comes along with a load of water.
translation_text.mn119:28.4: Could that person pour water into the jar?”
translation_text.mn119:28.6: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get an opportunity.
translation_text.mn119:29.1: When a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they extend the mind to realize by insight each and every thing that can be realized by insight; and they are capable of realizing those things, since each and every one is within range.
translation_text.mn119:29.2: Suppose a water jar was placed on a stand, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
translation_text.mn119:29.3: If a strong man was to pour it on any side, would water pour out?”
translation_text.mn119:29.5: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they extend the mind to realize by insight each and every thing that can be realized by insight; and they are capable of realizing those things, since each and every one is within range.
translation_text.mn119:30.1: Suppose there was a square, walled lotus pond on level ground, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
translation_text.mn119:30.2: If a strong man was to open the wall on any side, would water pour out?”
translation_text.mn119:30.4: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they extend the mind to realize by insight each and every thing that can be realized by insight; and they are capable of realizing those things, since each and every one is within range.
translation_text.mn119:31.1: Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready.
translation_text.mn119:31.2: A deft horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes.
translation_text.mn119:31.3: In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they extend the mind to realize by insight each and every thing that can be realized by insight; and they are capable of realizing those things, since each and every one is within range.
translation_text.mn119:32.1: You can expect ten benefits when mindfulness of the body has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.
translation_text.mn119:33.1: They prevail over desire and discontent, and live having mastered desire and discontent whenever they arose.
translation_text.mn119:34.1: They prevail over fear and dread, and live having mastered fear and dread whenever they arose.
translation_text.mn119:35.1: They endure cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; rude and unwelcome criticism; and put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.
translation_text.mn119:36.1: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
translation_text.mn119:37.1: They wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again … They control the body as far as the realm of divinity.
translation_text.mn119:38.1: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far. …
translation_text.mn119:39.1: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with their own mind. …
translation_text.mn119:40.1: They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn119:41.1: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn119:42.1: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn119:43.1: You can expect these ten benefits when mindfulness of the body has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.”
translation_text.mn119:43.2: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn119:43.3: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

variant_text.mn119:2.3: kāyagatāsati → kāyagatā sati (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)
variant_text.mn119:4.7: gehasitā → ye te gehasitā (pts1ed); ye gehassitā (ṭīkā)
variant_text.mn119:4.9: kāyagatāsatiṁ → kāyagataṁ satiṁ (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)
variant_text.mn119:8.3: vibhajitvā → paṭivibhajitvā (sya1ed, sya2ed, km); paṭibhajitvā (pts1ed) | catumahāpathe → cātummahāpathe (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)
variant_text.mn119:10.1: kulalehi vā khajjamānaṁ gijjhehi vā khajjamānaṁ kaṅkehi vā khajjamānaṁ sunakhehi vā khajjamānaṁ byagghehi vā khajjamānaṁ dīpīhi vā khajjamānaṁ siṅgālehi vā → gijjhehi vā khajjamānaṁ suvānehi vā khajjamānaṁ siṅgālehi vā (si), gijjhehi vā khajjamānaṁ kulalehi vā khajjamānaṁ suvāṇehi vā khajjamānaṁ siṅgālehi vā (sya-all, km), gijjhehi vā khajjamānaṁ suvāṇehi vā khajjamānaṁ sigālehi vā (pts1ed)
variant_text.mn119:11-14.4: aññena phāsukaṭṭhikaṁ aññena piṭṭhiṭṭhikaṁ aññena khandhaṭṭhikaṁ aññena gīvaṭṭhikaṁ aññena hanukaṭṭhikaṁ aññena dantaṭṭhikaṁ aññena sīsakaṭāhaṁ → aññena piṭṭhikaṇṭhikaṁ aññena sīsakaṭāhaṁ (si), aññena piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṭṭhikaṁ … aññena sīsakaṭāhaṁ (sya-all), aññena kaṭaṭṭhikaṁ aññena piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṁ aññena sīsakaṭāhaṁ (pts1ed)
variant_text.mn119:18.3: sāyaṁ nhānīyapiṇḍi → sāssa nahānīyapiṇḍi (bj, sya-all, km); sāsassa nahāniyapiṇḍī (pts1ed) | nhānīyacuṇṇāni → nahānīyacuṇṇāni (bj, sya-all, km); nahāniyacuṇṇāni (pts1ed) | nhāpako → nahāpako (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)
variant_text.mn119:24.1: bhikkhave, sukkhaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ koḷāpaṁ → koḷāpaṁ ārakā udakā thale nikkhittaṁ (mr)
variant_text.mn119:27.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, allaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ sasnehaṁ → sasnehaṁ ārakā udakā thale nikkhittaṁ (mr)
